author: Charles Moore
title: Margaret Thatcher biography part 4: Looking the part
text:
Follow 
Margaret Thatcher became a convert to the dictum of the famous Vogue editor Anna Wintour that “everything comes from the shoulders”, lessening the bust and narrowing the waist. 
A clearer, stronger look: Mrs Thatcher picked ensembles that worked better on television She had moved from the provincial-woman-looking-smart of the 1950s and 1960s, through the almost municipal styles of the 1970s – patterns, pussycat bows, waistcoats without sleeves, pie-crust frill blouses and designs which tended to make her shoulders look weak – to a clearer, stronger look[in the 1980s] which worked better on television. 
This clothed her in block colours – sapphire, cerise, jade green, canary yellow – which stood out against grey men, as well as the staple black, which suited her well. 
In some respects, she came to dress like the Queen , wearing, for example, thick-heeled patent-leather shoes, first from Rayne and later from Ferragamo, and carrying, of course, the famous patent-leather handbag. 
Those who advised her on clothes felt that she finally achieved her best style by 1987. “Her look solidified at its purest,” according to the fashion historian Jane Mulvagh: it was the sartorial expression of the mental control which she exercised over government. 
Margaret Thatcher with Ronald Regan at Downing Street in 1984 
“I introduced her to Dynasty padded shoulders,” claimed Carla Powell of the mid-1980s, whereas Crawfie (Cynthia Crawford, her long-standing assistant) considered that it was she who persuaded her that her way of dressing looked old-fashioned. 'She liked her hair soft. She liked it teased. She liked it rolled. She liked it sprayed' Eivind Bjerke, stylist 
She also catalogued all the clothes, noting which was worn when and naming them according to the place at which each appeared (“Kiev”, “Versailles”) or because of what they looked like (“Gloriana”). 
She was particularly pleased with the navy and white check suit which Mrs Thatcher wore in the election campaign, in which she “looked a million dollars”. 
Mrs Thatcher herself had a good memory for what she had worn when, and liked to wear old favourites, or, as she sometimes called them, “recipes”, revamped. 
The countryside look: Dressing for the campaign trail in Cornwall, 1983 
For someone who was so busy and needed to change fast, dresses were vulnerable and complicated: suits were better. 
She preferred sturdy tweeds, brocades and British wool to frail silks or linen, and was preoccupied with “a very good line”. 
Regal style: Thatcher came to dess like the Queen She was well upholstered, well covered and always perfectly groomed and coiffed, although, when travelling, she never took a hairdresser but relied on local stylists. 
“She had very nice hair [although] a little bit on the fine side,” recalled Eivind Bjerke, her stylist of choice in the US. 
“She liked it – in today’s parlance – a little bit old fashioned. She liked her hair soft. She liked it teased. She liked it rolled. She liked it sprayed. 
"It also had to be something that, when she was photographed from all angles, would look good.” 
Shortly before the 1987 general election, Mrs Thatcher visited Moscow and was looking for a coup de theatre. Crawfie told her, “if you’re going to Moscow, I think we’d better buy you some new clothes. Mrs Gorbachev always wears Yves Saint Laurent.” 
Margaret and Denis Thatcher with George Bush and his wife Barbara in 1987 Photo: Rex Features 
Crawfie saw a black coat in the window of Aquascutum, which she got on approval. She also found a camel-hair coat with a sable collar and borrowed a sable hat from a friend. 
Mrs Thatcher arrived in Moscow late on Saturday 28 March, and descended from the plane in her black coat and fur hat, carrying a black crocodile skin handbag. 
Thatcher and Denis on a state visit to Jordan in 1985, with King Hussein (centre) and the Jordanian Prime Minister (far right) 
Crawfie recalled, “she looked stunning”. She went to watch Swan Lake at the Bolshoi Theatre wearing a black lace evening dress lent to her by her friend Lady Glover. 
Everything comes from the shoulders: Thatcher was inspired by Vogue editor Anna Wintour She was never informal, because she instinctively recognised that this would invite a familiarity which would weaken her, but she had learnt from her mother, “do not sit around in good clothes”. 
She could never afford to be “flamboyant, daring, sexy”, she once told an interviewer ; and when asked where she bought her underwear, the reassuringly unsexy answer was Marks and Spencer. 
Although Mrs Thatcher’s style was, in a sense, conventional, she rejected the cliché of the female executive which sought to imitate men – the pinstripe, the dull navy suit. 
She made sure she stood out, and her female equivalent of armour made her feel powerful, but she knew that being powerful is like being a lady: if you have to tell people you are, you aren’t.
